column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

Cattle numbers increased to 366 penned. Quality was mostly plainer secondary types, although there was a good run of heavy cows yarded.  All the usual buying group attended with extraâ€™s on the rail in a stronger market across the yarding.  A limited offering of young cattle sold to 30c/kg stronger for the better quality and more in places. Grown steers and heifers lifted 10c to 20c, manufacturing types sold to 20c/kg dearer.  Heavy cows gained 8c, and the medium weights sold 10 to 20c/kg stronger.  Heavy Bulls were in demand again to be 15c/kg dearer.
 
Young cattle sold to the trade from 304c to 360c for the better quality, with one pen of Murray Gray yearling steers selling to 392c/kg. The secondary types sold from 170c to 280c/kg.  Feeders and restockers paid 120c to 368c/kg.  Grown Steers made from 326c to 352c, grown heifers sold to the trade from 242c to 340c, while restockers and feeders paid from 280c to 356c/kg. Manufacturing Beef steers made from 220c to 310c/kg.
 
Heavy cows sold from 290c to 348c/kg. Medium weights cows made from 226c to 260c and the light weights made from 80c to 210c/kg.  Dairy cows sold from 230c to 240c/kg. Heavy bulls sold from 284c to 348c and the lighter and younger bulls made from 184c to 284c/kg..
 
Market Reporter, Sheona Lamb
